article.title: Interaction effects in a microscopic quantum wire model with strong spin-orbit interaction

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the SO gap, depicted in Figure 1a, represent?
choices: The energy difference between the two lowest energy bands at k=π.
The energy difference between spin up and spin down states at k=0.
The energy difference between the two spin-split bands at k=0, induced by the Zeeman field.
The energy difference between the two highest energy bands at k=π/2.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1, what is the main difference between the helical LL (b) and the spiral LL (c)?
choices: The spiral LL includes gapped modes, while the helical LL does not.
The spiral LL has a larger SO gap compared to the helical LL.
The helical LL displays spin-charge separation, while the spiral LL does not.
The helical LL is only applicable for attractive interactions, while the spiral LL can be used for both attractive and repulsive interactions.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 1a, what is the effect of the Rashba SO coupling on the energy bands in the absence of a Zeeman field (dashed lines)?
choices: It shifts both branches of the dispersion relation to higher energies.
It shifts both branches of the dispersion relation to lower energies.
It shifts the two degenerate bands in opposite directions by a momentum kSO.
It introduces a gap at k = 0, lifting the degeneracy of the two bands.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the arrows in Figure 1a indicate?
choices: The direction of motion for electrons in each band.
The direction of the applied magnetic field.
The spin direction of the eigenvectors for B = 0.2.
The momentum direction of the allowed excitations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the formula k<sub>SO</sub> = arctan(α/t) represent?
choices: The Fermi momentum of the system.
The Zeeman energy splitting.
The momentum shift induced by the Rashba spin-orbit coupling.
The energy gap in the presence of the Zeeman field.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the parameter B<sup>*</sup> in formula (3.1)?
choices: It represents the bare Zeeman field applied to the system.
It signifies the critical interaction strength for the Mott transition.
It represents the renormalized SO gap in the presence of interactions.
It quantifies the energy difference between the first and second breather states.

multiple_choice_question.text: What physical phenomena does formula (3.7), Δ<sub>l</sub> = 2B<sup>*</sup>sin(lπκ/(8-2κ)), describe?
choices: The emergence of a Mott insulating phase at strong interactions.
The emergence of breather bound states in the presence of attractive interactions in the SGM.
The renormalization of the Fermi velocity due to electron-electron interactions.
The suppression of the local spectral weight at the boundary of the system.
